Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Mountains of the Milky Way
Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of stars are born in small clusters with other stars. These clusters are thus the basic building blocks of galaxies. These clusters start out as clouds of molecular gas, which turn into stars over millions of years. A number of fundamental questions about star cluster formation are still debated, including "exactly how long does it take"? and "how much of the gas in the clouds turned into clusters stars"?

Based on their previous observations of the distribution of molecular clouds, they have argued for relatively long formation times. With this assumption of slow star formation, they will compare the types of molecules detected in our galaxy with the chemical relationships between the molecules. They will match their observations to find the correct chemical models. They have thousands of hours of previous observations which they will use to answer these questions. Also they will fully calibrate the data in a manner useful to other astronomers studying star formation.

Because they have measurements of a large part of the center of our galaxy, they will relate the chemical structure on small scales with our galaxy's large scale structure. On the larger, galaxy-sized, scales there are also many open issues related to the basic question of how star move from small clusters, and in the process, destroying the molecular clouds which were the birthplaces of the stars.

This research will be integrated into the teaching activities, including additions to the introductory astronomy course, Discover the Universe, he teaches each year to hundreds of students at the University of Florida. They will develop a new public outreach presentation based on this research, entitled "Molecular Mountains of the Milky Way", which will be presented in local schools and at the Starry Night public outreach event he helps organize at the Florida Museum of Natural History.

In addition, this proposal will directly contribute towards the training of two Ph.D. students. One of the main research products will be the molecular line survey data, made publicly available to the astronomical community via the internet. During this proposal period the PI will organize an international conference on star formation in Florida, part of which will be devoted to the results from Galactic plane surveys that connect star formations to the structure of our Galaxy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to test theoretical models of star formation, especially star cluster formation. This is important because we think that most stars form in clusters, perhaps including our own Sun.

The first sub-goal was to reduce observational survey data of molecular line emission from dense gas clumps in our Galaxy, recorded by the Mopra telescope in Australia. These clumps may be the progenitors of star clusters. The second sub-goal was to analyze these data, along with ancillary multi-wavelength data from other telescopes, to determine the physical and chemical properties of the clumps.

The third sub-goal was to use these results to test and develop theoretical models of star cluster formation, including three aspects: (i) constraining the star formation rate of the clusters; (ii) develop and test models of astrochemical evolution; (iii) understand the relation of the molecular clump population to the larger scale interstellar medium.

While several research papers towards some of the above goals were published during the grant period, the full goals of the project could not be met. This was due to the fact that the PhD student who was mostly supported by the project to carry out the proposed work, was prevented from including his work in his PhD thesis because of a dispute with one of the project's team members. The student and the PI of the project (Tan), who was the student's PhD advisor, suffered harassment (emails were sent to research journal editors with false accusations about the student and PI), which was the subject of a documented U. Florida Human Resources (HR) investigation. Unfortunately the U. Florida administration (within the Astronomy Dept. and the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences) were not able to resolve this matter to the satisfaction of the student and the PI, who felt that there was a continued violation of their academic freedom to work on the public domain data to carry out the project that had been proposed to NSF. Also the administration was not able to ensure that the work environment was free from harassment and bullying to the satisfaction of the PI and student, following the results of the HR investigation. As a result of these difficulties, the project was not able to progress as originally proposed. The PI felt the need to find a new research institution with a better working environment and this was achieved by 2017, when the PhD student was also able to graduate and leave UF. The PI and former student intend to now continue the work they started to complete the full goals of the original proposal.

One of the main proposed broader impacts of the project was the training of the PhD student. While this was achieved, it was not done to the full satisfaction of the PI and student due to the above mentioned problems.
